Award.AwardTitle: Boundary Element Methods (BEM) Adjoint-based Active Surfaces for Next-Generation Surface Wave Testing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In recent years, there have been several important innovations that have increased the accuracy and reliability of surface wave methods used in geotechnical and earthquake engineering. However, one aspect of surface wave testing that has changed little in 30 years is the subsurface forward model underlying the inverse problem. The most widely used one is a horizontally layered model with soil properties that vary only in the vertical direction. Further advancement of surface wave methods in geotechnical engineering is thus limited by the lack of robust and efficient computational models that enable more realistic representations of two- or three-dimensional soil media. This research will formulate a new class of geometric numerical inverse models for surface wave measurements that will lead to more realistic modeling of subsurface soil properties than the current state of the art and consequently more accurate subsurface characterization. Using a multidisciplinary approach, a powerful new class of innovative computational models, referred to as "BEM Adjoint-based Active Surfaces," will be derived to solve the geometric inverse problem of the identification of the spatially varying soil properties in heterogeneous elastic media directly from raw data via the Boundary Element Method (BEM).

The derived inverse model will represent a major change in extracting unseen geometric structures from digital surface measurements, where the standard procedure is to transform the raw sensor data into more intuitive volumetric data (e.g., cross-sectional images), from which geometric features (such as layer boundaries) can then be extracted afterward via signal and image processing methods. This new inverse model paradigm will offer a new computational method to pass directly from raw tomographic measurements to potentially complex geometric shapes (such as geometry of thickness varying layer interfaces, soil occlusions or cavity identification). The new inverse methods will also be applicable to a broader set of non-invasive wave propagation characterization techniques for civil infrastructure. The investigators will incorporate the research into graduate courses on solid mechanics, image processing, in-situ seismic testing, and geometric inverse problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Highlights

1)    Initial exploration of several concepts that form the foundation for a geometric theory for adjoint active surface imaging

2)    Formulated geometric inverse methods for geotechnical/geophysical engineering and acoustics. 

3)    Graduated two Ph.D students.

4)    Lab experiments at Georgia Tech  have been performed to test and apply the developed geometric theory in (1).

5)   Observed as serendipity that solid elastic waves have similar physical properties as dispersive ocean waves.

6)    The unexpected relation between solid elastic waves and ocean waves in (5)  has triggered new ideas on how to explain extreme events of wave motion and their statistics.

7)    Research published in the high impact factor journal IEEE Transactions on Image Processing (IF=3.111).

 

INTELLECTUAL MERITS: We have undertaken an initial and extensive exploration of a number of concepts that form the basis for a theory of adjoint active surface imaging.  Specifically, the use of geometric inverse methods for two physical models have been explored: the scalar Helmholtz equation and vector elastodynamics with applications in geotechnical/geophysical engineering, acoustics and other fields such biomedical ultrasound. The performed research focused on evaluating the efficiency and trade-offs of modeling methods using meshless boundary elements methods by means of the Method of Fundamental Solutions.

 

BROADER IMPACTS: Two graduate students were involved in the research and one postdoctoral research associate was brought into the collaboration. The two graduate students and the postdoc gained valuable experience collaborating in the context of a larger team. The novelty and promise shown in the carried research was compelling enough to expand the research team and obtain an NSF EAGER award #1347191, “Shape Based Tomographic Inversion for Maximal Geometric Resolution.”. We also have submitted a large collaborative NSF proposal: “CIF:Large: Collaborative Research: Unified geometric and physics-based reconstruction to characterize embedded volumetric anomalies across multidisciplinary sensing modalities”.

Further, laboratory experiments at Georgia Tech have been performed to test and apply the developed theory for adjoint active surface imaging to the scattering of ultrasonic Lamb waves traveling in a thin plate. We have discovered as serendipity that solid elastic waves have similar properties as those observed in ocean waves. In particular, the PI Fedele recently highlighted an unnoticed property of ocean waves the crest slowdown. This is due to wave dispersion  and a similar phenomenon is also observed in expanding Lamb waves. The unexpected relation between solid elastic waves and water waves was a surprise and it has triggered new ideas on how to explain extreme events of wave motion and their statistics.

A long-term general program of research has been jump-started by both the mathematical analysis and the computational codes they generated. The two Ph.D. students graduated and published their research in the high impact factor journal IEEE Transactions on Image Processing (IF=3.111).
